entry.title: Combined summary - BIP 322 use case
entry.summary:
The discussion around the use of signed messages within the Bitcoin community, particularly in relation to BIP322, underscores a complex landscape of technical and regulatory challenges. The primary intended use case for BIP322, which is facilitating agreement to contracts before the transfer of funds, has not garnered significant interest. This lack of enthusiasm may stem from alternative perspectives on its application, especially the controversial proposition of employing signed messages for KYC purposes. Such an approach has been met with resistance, as it diverges from the traditional financial sector's reliance on simpler forms of attestation, like checkboxes, to verify user actions or intentions.
Moreover, the exploration into BIP322 reveals a nuanced demand within the Bitcoin ecosystem for functionalities beyond its original scope, such as proof-of-funds and proof-of-sender. These demands highlight the evolving needs of users and the technological hurdles in meeting them. Despite these challenges, there is evidence of partial adoption of BIP322 by some wallets, indicating a recognition of its utility even in an unfinished state. The prospect of advancing or amending BIP322 necessitates the development of a new Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP), given the complexities involved and the specific requirements of the community.
A practical illustration of these challenges is provided by a Bitcoin association's experience, as shared in their communication. Their inability to sign an address with a multi-sig wallet for KYC purposes, despite utilizing tools like "Swiss Bitcoin Pay" for membership management and merchant onboarding, showcases the operational implications of the current limitations of BIP322. This situation is further complicated in jurisdictions where such cryptographic proof is mandated by law. The association's reliance on multi-sig wallets, aimed at decentralizing their treasury akin to many companies, highlights the broader implications for the Bitcoin ecosystem. The necessity for BIP322 enhancements becomes apparent, not only to facilitate existing operations but also to potentially unlock new capabilities within the ecosystem. The dialogue underscores an urgent call for collaborative efforts to address these deficiencies, with an openness to contribution and improvement from the community. For more information on the discussions leading to these insights, references to the relevant threads can be found [here](https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5408898.0) and [here](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1347).
